awd_titl_txt: Problems in mathematical foundations of adaptive finite element methods
awd_abstract_narration:
A posteriori error estimates and adaptive finite element methods (AFEM) are widely-used tools for solving partial differential equations (PDEs) arising in science and engineering applications.  A posteriori estimates provide computable bounds on discretization errors, while AFEM are efficient solution techniques which accurately reflect solution properties via automatic local mesh grading.  The goals of this project are to better understand the mathematical underpinnings of AFEM and to provide new a posteriori error estimates and adaptive algorithms in several specific application areas.  A major part of the project is devoted to development and analysis of a posteriori error estimates and AFEM for PDEs on surfaces.  Specific projects concern Eulerian formulations of parabolic PDEs on evolving surfaces, solution of elliptic PDEs on surfaces for which the only available information is a discrete approximation, and elliptic eigenvalue problems.  Another emphasis is fine properties of FEM, in particular the development of a priori and a posteriori error estimates in nonstandard norms.  The PI will develop new a priori error estimates in such norms on the types of highly graded meshes typically seen in practice, prove new a posteriori maximum-norm bounds for elliptic interface problems, and integrate similar error analysis into his study of surface eigenvalue problems. 

A wide variety of applications in science and engineering give rise to partial differential equations (PDEs) which must be solved in order to obtain accurate predictions about the physical world.  PDEs are typically solved approximately on computers in modern applications, and there is a tradeoff between the quality of the approximate solution and the investment of computational resources.  The PI will study the mathematical underpinnings of adaptive algorithms which automatically generate more accurate solutions while efficiently employing the computing power at hand.  Part of the project is aimed at enriching mathematical understanding of existing algorithms, and part to developing new and mathematically well-justified adaptive algorithms for various applications.

por.por_cntn:
Partial differential equations are widely used in science and engineering to model phenomena such as aircraft dynamics, human physiology, and finance.  In order to make accurate predictions using these equations, they typically are solved approximately using numerical (computer) algorithms.  In this project the PI studied the mathematical foundations of one of the main numerical methods for solving partial differential equations, the finite element method.  There were two main foci of the project.  The first is surface finite element methods, in which differential equations are posed on a surface such as the interface between a drop of oil and water in which it is situated.  A second focus is adaptivity.  Finite element methods work by breaking a complicated geomtric area (such as an aircraft) into simple entities such as triangles.  Adaptive algorithms decide in an automated way how to place more triangles in the mesh.  Placing more triangles in the mesh has two effects:  First, it should increase the quality of the solution, that is, yield more accurate results.  Second, it raises the cost of the algorithm.  Thus the goal of adaptivity is to automatically allocate scarce resources in an optimal way.  

The project advanced basic knowledge about surface finite element methods by generating a new surface FEM and by providing new insight into error behavior of eigenvalue problems on surfaces.  Eigenvalue problems are important in various applications as they roughly speaking provide a signature of the shape of an object and also information about frequencies it can generate when vibrating.  Surface eigenvalue problems have for example been used to classify brain scans as normal or abnormal.  The project also resulted in new insight into the behavior of adaptive methods for computing eigenvalues.  The project also resulted in the definition and analysis of other types of adaptive algorithms.  In addition to these scientific outcomes, the project supported the training of a doctoral student in mathematics.
